constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (e.g. US 2 letter state codes).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

definition.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
definition.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

definition.short: Version of the system - if relevant
definition.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
definition.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Plain text representation of the concept
definition.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
definition.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
definition.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

definition.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
definition.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means no end was known or planned at the time the instance was created. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
definition.comment: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has an end value of 2012-02-03.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
definition.comment: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

definition.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values.
definition.comment: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

output.valueCount._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for Count Type: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
output.valueCount._root.name: Count

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
definition.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
definition.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
definition.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

definition.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
definition.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
definition.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

definition.short: A code-valued attribute to filter on
definition.definition: The code-valued attribute of the filter. The specified path SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the specified type of the DataRequirement, and SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve(). The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details). Note that the index must be an integer constant. The path must resolve to an element of type code, Coding, or CodeableConcept.
definition.comment: The path attribute contains a [Simple FHIRPath Subset](fhirpath.html#simple) that allows path traversal, but not calculation.

If a Duration is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within Duration before now.

Indicates that specific elements of the type are referenced by the knowledge module and must be supported by the consumer in order to obtain an effective evaluation. This does not mean that a value is required for this element, only that the consuming system must understand the element and be able to provide values for it if they are available. 

The value of mustSupport SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the type of the DataRequirement. The path SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve() (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details).

Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.

Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should reference to some definition that establishes the system clearly and unambiguously.
definition.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
definition.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Logical reference, when literal reference is not known
definition.definition: An identifier for the target resource. This is used when there is no way to reference the other resource directly, either because the entity it represents is not available through a FHIR server, or because there is no way for the author of the resource to convert a known identifier to an actual location. There is no requirement that a Reference.identifier point to something that is actually exposed as a FHIR instance, but it SHALL point to a business concept that would be expected to be exposed as a FHIR instance, and that instance would need to be of a FHIR resource type allowed by the reference.
definition.comment:
When an identifier is provided in place of a reference, any system processing the reference will only be able to resolve the identifier to a reference if it understands the business context in which the identifier is used. Sometimes this is global (e.g. a national identifier) but often it is not. For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy. 

When both an identifier and a literal reference are provided, the literal reference is preferred. Applications processing the resource are allowed - but not required - to check that the identifier matches the literal reference

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

Reference is intended to point to a structure that can potentially be expressed as a FHIR resource, though there is no need for it to exist as an actual FHIR resource instance - except in as much as an application wishes to actual find the target of the reference. The content referred to be the identifier must meet the logical constraints implied by any limitations on what resource types are permitted for the reference.  For example, it would not be legitimate to send the identifier for a drug prescription if the type were Reference(Observation|DiagnosticReport).  One of the use-cases for Reference.identifier is the situation where no FHIR representation exists (where the type is Reference (Any).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Literal reference, Relative, internal or absolute URL
definition.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comment: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/ e.g. "Patient" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient. output.valueReference._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for Reference Type: A reference from one resource to another.
output.valueReference._root.name: Reference

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
definition.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Logical reference, when literal reference is not known
definition.definition: An identifier for the target resource. This is used when there is no way to reference the other resource directly, either because the entity it represents is not available through a FHIR server, or because there is no way for the author of the resource to convert a known identifier to an actual location. There is no requirement that a Reference.identifier point to something that is actually exposed as a FHIR instance, but it SHALL point to a business concept that would be expected to be exposed as a FHIR instance, and that instance would need to be of a FHIR resource type allowed by the reference.
definition.comment:
When an identifier is provided in place of a reference, any system processing the reference will only be able to resolve the identifier to a reference if it understands the business context in which the identifier is used. Sometimes this is global (e.g. a national identifier) but often it is not. For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy. 

When both an identifier and a literal reference are provided, the literal reference is preferred. Applications processing the resource are allowed - but not required - to check that the identifier matches the literal reference

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

Reference is intended to point to a structure that can potentially be expressed as a FHIR resource, though there is no need for it to exist as an actual FHIR resource instance - except in as much as an application wishes to actual find the target of the reference. The content referred to be the identifier must meet the logical constraints implied by any limitations on what resource types are permitted for the reference.  For example, it would not be legitimate to send the identifier for a drug prescription if the type were Reference(Observation|DiagnosticReport).  One of the use-cases for Reference.identifier is the situation where no FHIR representation exists (where the type is Reference (Any).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Literal reference, Relative, internal or absolute URL
definition.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comment: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition:
The expected type of the target of the reference. If both Reference.type and Reference.reference are populated and Reference.reference is a FHIR URL, both SHALL be consistent.

The type is the Canonical URL of Resource Definition that is the type this reference refers to. References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/ e.g. "Patient" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient. Absolute URLs are only allowed for logical models (and can only be used in references in logical models, not resources).
definition.comment: This element is used to indicate the type of  the target of the reference. This may be used which ever of the other elements are populated (or not). In some cases, the type of the target may be determined by inspection of the reference (e.g. a RESTful URL) or by resolving the target of the reference; if both the type and a reference is provided, the reference SHALL resolve to a resource of the same type as that specified.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Aa resource (or, for logical models, the URI of the logical model).

definition.definition: The value of the Output parameter as a basic type.
definition.requirements: Task outputs can take any form.

output.valueRelatedArtifact._root.name: RelatedArtifact

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
A bibliographic citation for the related artifact. This text SHOULD be formatted according to an accepted citation format.
definition.comment: Additional structured information about citations should be captured as extensions.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Brief description of the related artifact
definition.definition: A brief description of the document or knowledge resource being referenced, suitable for display to a consumer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The document being referenced, represented as an attachment. This is exclusive with the resource element.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueRelatedArtifact.document._ro.description: Base StructureDefinition for Attachment Type: For referring to data content defined in other formats.
output.valueRelatedArtifact.document._ro.name: Attachment

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

definition.short: Mime type of the content, with charset etc.
definition.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
definition.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

definition.definition: The date that the attachment was first created.
definition.requirements: This is often tracked as an integrity issue for use of the attachment.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes, base64 encoded.
definition.comment: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
definition.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
definition.comment: The hash is calculated on the data prior to base64 encoding, if the data is based64 encoded. The hash is not intended to support digital signatures. Where protection against malicious threats a digital signature should be considered, see [Provenance.signature](provenance-definitions.html#Provenance.signature) for mechanism to protect a resource with a digital signature.
definition.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed due to technical failures (e.g., storage rot, transport glitch, incorrect version).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
definition.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A human language.

definition.short: Number of bytes of content (if url provided)
definition.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment (before base64 encoding, if that is done).
definition.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
definition.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Label to display in place of the data
definition.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.
definition.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Uri where the data can be found
definition.definition: A location where the data can be accessed.
definition.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
definition.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

definition.definition: A short label that can be used to reference the citation from elsewhere in the containing artifact, such as a footnote index.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The related resource, such as a library, value set, profile, or other knowledge resource.
definition.comment: If the type is predecessor, this is a reference to the succeeding knowledge resource. If the type is successor, this is a reference to the prior knowledge resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: documentation | justification | citation | predecessor | successor | derived-from | depends-on | composed-of
definition.definition: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of relationship to the related artifact.

definition.short: Where the artifact can be accessed
definition.definition: A url for the artifact that can be followed to access the actual content.
definition.comment: If a document or resource element is present, this element SHALL NOT be provided (use the url or reference in the Attachment or resource reference).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.requirements: Task outputs can take any form.

output.valueSampledData._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for SampledData Type: A series of measurements taken by a device, with upper and lower limits. There may be more than one dimension in the data.
output.valueSampledData._root.name: SampledData

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

A series of data points which are decimal values separated by a single space (character u20). The special values "E" (error), "L" (below detection limit) and "U" (above detection limit) can also be used in place of a decimal value.
definition.comment: Data may be missing if it is omitted for summarization purposes. In general, data is required for any actual use of a SampledData.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Number of sample points at each time point
definition.definition: The number of sample points at each time point. If this value is greater than one, then the dimensions will be interlaced - all the sample points for a point in time will be recorded at once.
definition.comment: If there is more than one dimension, the code for the type of data will define the meaning of the dimensions (typically ECG data).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Multiply data by this before adding to origin
definition.definition: A correction factor that is applied to the sampled data points before they are added to the origin.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If no factor is assigned, the data is not adjusted before adding to the origin

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueSampledData.origin._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for Quantity Type: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). Note that measured amounts include amounts that are not precisely quantified, including amounts involving arbitrary units and floating currencies.
output.valueSampledData.origin._root.name: Quantity

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
definition.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
definition.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
definition.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

definition.short: System that defines coded unit form

definition.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
definition.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
definition.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
definition.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The length of time between sampling times, measured in milliseconds.

output.valueSignature._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for Signature Type: A signature along with supporting context. The signature may be a digital signature that is cryptographic in nature, or some other signature acceptable to the domain. This other signature may be as simple as a graphical image representing a hand-written signature, or a signature ceremony Different signature approaches have different utilities.
output.valueSignature._root.name: Signature

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

definition.short: The actual signature content (XML DigSig. JWS, picture, etc.)
definition.definition: The base64 encoding of the Signature content. When signature is not recorded electronically this element would be empty.
definition.comment: Where the signature type is an XML DigSig, the signed content is a FHIR Resource(s), the signature is of the XML form of the Resource(s) using  XML-Signature (XMLDIG) "Detached Signature" form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueSignature.onBehalfOf._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for Reference Type: A reference from one resource to another.
output.valueSignature.onBehalfOf._root.name: Reference

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
definition.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Logical reference, when literal reference is not known
definition.definition: An identifier for the target resource. This is used when there is no way to reference the other resource directly, either because the entity it represents is not available through a FHIR server, or because there is no way for the author of the resource to convert a known identifier to an actual location. There is no requirement that a Reference.identifier point to something that is actually exposed as a FHIR instance, but it SHALL point to a business concept that would be expected to be exposed as a FHIR instance, and that instance would need to be of a FHIR resource type allowed by the reference.
definition.comment:
When an identifier is provided in place of a reference, any system processing the reference will only be able to resolve the identifier to a reference if it understands the business context in which the identifier is used. Sometimes this is global (e.g. a national identifier) but often it is not. For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy. 

When both an identifier and a literal reference are provided, the literal reference is preferred. Applications processing the resource are allowed - but not required - to check that the identifier matches the literal reference

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

Reference is intended to point to a structure that can potentially be expressed as a FHIR resource, though there is no need for it to exist as an actual FHIR resource instance - except in as much as an application wishes to actual find the target of the reference. The content referred to be the identifier must meet the logical constraints implied by any limitations on what resource types are permitted for the reference.  For example, it would not be legitimate to send the identifier for a drug prescription if the type were Reference(Observation|DiagnosticReport).  One of the use-cases for Reference.identifier is the situation where no FHIR representation exists (where the type is Reference (Any).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Literal reference, Relative, internal or absolute URL
definition.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comment: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition:
The expected type of the target of the reference. If both Reference.type and Reference.reference are populated and Reference.reference is a FHIR URL, both SHALL be consistent.

The type is the Canonical URL of Resource Definition that is the type this reference refers to. References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/ e.g. "Patient" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient. Absolute URLs are only allowed for logical models (and can only be used in references in logical models, not resources).
definition.comment: This element is used to indicate the type of  the target of the reference. This may be used which ever of the other elements are populated (or not). In some cases, the type of the target may be determined by inspection of the reference (e.g. a RESTful URL) or by resolving the target of the reference; if both the type and a reference is provided, the reference SHALL resolve to a resource of the same type as that specified.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Aa resource (or, for logical models, the URI of the logical model).

definition.short: The technical format of the signature

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

definition.short: The technical format of the signed resources
definition.definition: A mime type that indicates the technical format of the target resources signed by the signature.
definition.comment: "xml", "json" and "ttl" are allowed, which describe the simple encodings described in the specification (and imply appropriate bundle support). Otherwise, mime types are legal here.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

definition.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

definition.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
definition.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should reference to some definition that establishes the system clearly and unambiguously.
definition.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
definition.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - e.g. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
definition.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
definition.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Version of the system - if relevant
definition.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. output.valueTriggerDefinition._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for TriggerDefinition Type: A description of a triggering event. Triggering events can be named events, data events, or periodic, as determined by the type element.
output.valueTriggerDefinition._root.name: TriggerDefinition

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
A boolean-valued expression that is evaluated in the context of the container of the trigger definition and returns whether or not the trigger fires.
definition.comment: This element can be only be specified for data type triggers and provides additional semantics for the trigger. The context available within the condition is based on the type of data event. For all events, the current resource will be available as context. In addition, for modification events, the previous resource will also be available. The expression may be inlined, or may be a simple absolute URI, which is a reference to a named expression within a logic library referenced by a library element or extension within the containing resource. If the expression is a FHIR Path expression, it evaluates in the context of a resource of one of the type identified in the data requirement, and may also refer to the variable %previous for delta comparisons on events of type data-changed, data-modified, and data-deleted which will always have the same type.
definition.requirements: Need to be able to formally describe the triggering criteria.

definition.short: A code-valued attribute to filter on
definition.definition: The code-valued attribute of the filter. The specified path SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the specified type of the DataRequirement, and SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve(). The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details). Note that the index must be an integer constant. The path must resolve to an element of type code, Coding, or CodeableConcept.

definition.definition: The value of the filter. If period is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within the bounds determined by the Period, inclusive of the period boundaries. If dateTime is specified, the filter will return only those data items that are equal to the specified dateTime. If a Duration is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within Duration before now.

definition.short: The value of the filter, as a Period, DateTime, or Duration value
definition.definition: The value of the filter. If period is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within the bounds determined by the Period, inclusive of the period boundaries. If dateTime is specified, the filter will return only those data items that are equal to the specified dateTime. If a Duration is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within Duration before now.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.dateF.description: Base StructureDefinition for Duration Type: A length of time.
output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.dateF.name: Duration

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
definition.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
definition.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
definition.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

binding.description: How the Quantity should be understood and represented.

definition.short: System that defines coded unit form
definition.definition: The identification of the system that provides the coded form of the unit.
definition.requirements: Need to know the system that defines the coded form of the unit.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: A human-readable form of the unit.
definition.requirements: There are many representations for units of measure and in many contexts, particular representations are fixed and required. I.e. mcg for micrograms.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The value of the measured amount. The value includes an implicit precision in the presentation of the value.
definition.comment: The implicit precision in the value should always be honored. Monetary values have their own rules for handling precision (refer to standard accounting text books).
definition.requirements: Precision is handled implicitly in almost all cases of measurement.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: PQ.value, CO.value, MO.value, IVL.high or IVL.low depending on the value

If dateTime is specified, the filter will return only those data items that are equal to the specified dateTime. If a Duration is specified, the filter will return only those data items that fall within Duration before now.

output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.dateF.description: Base StructureDefinition for Period Type: A time period defined by a start and end date and optionally time.
output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.dateF.name: Period

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

definition.short: End time with inclusive boundary, if not ongoing
definition.definition: The end of the period. If the end of the period is missing, it means no end was known or planned at the time the instance was created. The start may be in the past, and the end date in the future, which means that period is expected/planned to end at that time.
definition.comment: The high value includes any matching date/time. i.e. 2012-02-03T10:00:00 is in a period that has an end value of 2012-02-03.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If the end of the period is missing, it means that the period is ongoing

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: The start of the period. The boundary is inclusive.
definition.comment: If the low element is missing, the meaning is that the low boundary is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: Specifies a maximum number of results that are required (uses the _count search parameter).
definition.comment: This element can be used in combination with the sort element to specify quota requirements such as "the most recent 5" or "the highest 5".
definition.requirements: Enables the requirement "most recent 5 results" to be expressed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Indicates specific structure elements that are referenced by the knowledge module
definition.definition:
Indicates that specific elements of the type are referenced by the knowledge module and must be supported by the consumer in order to obtain an effective evaluation. This does not mean that a value is required for this element, only that the consuming system must understand the element and be able to provide values for it if they are available. 

The value of mustSupport SHALL be a FHIRPath resolveable on the type of the DataRequirement. The path SHALL consist only of identifiers, constant indexers, and .resolve() (see the [Simple FHIRPath Profile](fhirpath.html#simple) for full details).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: The profile of the required data
definition.definition: The profile of the required data, specified as the uri of the profile definition.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: Specifies the order of the results to be returned.
definition.comment: This element can be used in combination with the sort element to specify quota requirements such as "the most recent 5" or "the highest 5". When multiple sorts are specified, they are applied in the order they appear in the resource.
definition.requirements: Enables the requirement "most recent 5 results" to be expressed.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.sort..description: Specifies the order of the results to be returned.

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
The direction of the sort, ascending or descending.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The possible sort directions, ascending or descending.

definition.short: The name of the attribute to perform the sort
definition.definition: The attribute of the sort. The specified path must be resolvable from the type of the required data. The path is allowed to contain qualifiers (.) to traverse sub-elements, as well as indexers ([x]) to traverse multiple-cardinality sub-elements. Note that the index must be an integer constant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: E.g. Patient, Practitioner, RelatedPerson, Organization, Location, Device
definition.definition: The intended subjects of the data requirement. If this element is not provided, a Patient subject is assumed.
definition.comment: The subject of a data requirement is critical, as the data being specified is determined with respect to a particular subject. This corresponds roughly to the notion of a Compartment in that it limits what data is available based on its relationship to the subject. In CQL, this corresponds to the context declaration.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: Patient

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The possible types of subjects for a data requirement (E.g., Patient, Practitioner, Organization, Location, etc.).

output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.subje.name: CodeableConcept

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

definition.short: Code defined by a terminology system
definition.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
definition.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
definition.requirements: Allows for alternative encodings within a code system, and translations to other code systems.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.subje.description: Base StructureDefinition for Coding Type: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.subje.name: Coding

definition.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
definition.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
definition.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
definition.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

definition.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
definition.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should reference to some definition that establishes the system clearly and unambiguously.
definition.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
definition.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - e.g. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
definition.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
definition.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

definition.short: Version of the system - if relevant
definition.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
definition.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Plain text representation of the concept
definition.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
definition.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
definition.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.subje.description: Base StructureDefinition for Reference Type: A reference from one resource to another.
output.valueTriggerDefinition.data.subje.name: Reference

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
definition.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Logical reference, when literal reference is not known
definition.definition: An identifier for the target resource. This is used when there is no way to reference the other resource directly, either because the entity it represents is not available through a FHIR server, or because there is no way for the author of the resource to convert a known identifier to an actual location. There is no requirement that a Reference.identifier point to something that is actually exposed as a FHIR instance, but it SHALL point to a business concept that would be expected to be exposed as a FHIR instance, and that instance would need to be of a FHIR resource type allowed by the reference.
definition.comment:
When an identifier is provided in place of a reference, any system processing the reference will only be able to resolve the identifier to a reference if it understands the business context in which the identifier is used. Sometimes this is global (e.g. a national identifier) but often it is not. For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy. 

When both an identifier and a literal reference are provided, the literal reference is preferred. Applications processing the resource are allowed - but not required - to check that the identifier matches the literal reference

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

Reference is intended to point to a structure that can potentially be expressed as a FHIR resource, though there is no need for it to exist as an actual FHIR resource instance - except in as much as an application wishes to actual find the target of the reference. The content referred to be the identifier must meet the logical constraints implied by any limitations on what resource types are permitted for the reference.  For example, it would not be legitimate to send the identifier for a drug prescription if the type were Reference(Observation|DiagnosticReport).  One of the use-cases for Reference.identifier is the situation where no FHIR representation exists (where the type is Reference (Any).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Literal reference, Relative, internal or absolute URL
definition.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comment: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition:
The expected type of the target of the reference. If both Reference.type and Reference.reference are populated and Reference.reference is a FHIR URL, both SHALL be consistent.

The type is the Canonical URL of Resource Definition that is the type this reference refers to. References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/ e.g. "Patient" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient. Absolute URLs are only allowed for logical models (and can only be used in references in logical models, not resources).
definition.comment: This element is used to indicate the type of  the target of the reference. This may be used which ever of the other elements are populated (or not). In some cases, the type of the target may be determined by inspection of the reference (e.g. a RESTful URL) or by resolving the target of the reference; if both the type and a reference is provided, the reference SHALL resolve to a resource of the same type as that specified.

definition.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should reference to some definition that establishes the system clearly and unambiguously.
definition.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
definition.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - e.g. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
definition.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
definition.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

definition.short: Version of the system - if relevant
definition.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
definition.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Plain text representation of the concept
definition.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
definition.comment: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.
definition.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

output.valueUsageContext.valueQuantity._.description: Base StructureDefinition for Quantity Type: A measured amount (or an amount that can potentially be measured). output.valueUsageContext.valueQuantity._.name: Quantity

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
A computer processable form of the unit in some unit representation system.
definition.comment: The preferred system is UCUM, but SNOMED CT can also be used (for customary units) or ISO 4217 for currency.  The context of use may additionally require a code from a particular system.
definition.requirements: Need a computable form of the unit that is fixed across all forms. UCUM provides this for quantities, but SNOMED CT provides many units of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: How the value should be understood and represented - whether the actual value is greater or less than the stated value due to measurement issues; e.g. if the comparator is "<" , then the real value is < stated value.
definition.requirements: Need a framework for handling measures where the value is <5ug/L or >400mg/L due to the limitations of measuring methodology.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because the comparator modifies the interpretation of the value significantly. If there is no comparator, then there is no modification of the value

output.valueUsageContext.valueReference..description: Base StructureDefinition for Reference Type: A reference from one resource to another.
output.valueUsageContext.valueReference..name: Reference

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.
Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
definition.comment: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Logical reference, when literal reference is not known
definition.definition: An identifier for the target resource. This is used when there is no way to reference the other resource directly, either because the entity it represents is not available through a FHIR server, or because there is no way for the author of the resource to convert a known identifier to an actual location. There is no requirement that a Reference.identifier point to something that is actually exposed as a FHIR instance, but it SHALL point to a business concept that would be expected to be exposed as a FHIR instance, and that instance would need to be of a FHIR resource type allowed by the reference.
definition.comment:
When an identifier is provided in place of a reference, any system processing the reference will only be able to resolve the identifier to a reference if it understands the business context in which the identifier is used. Sometimes this is global (e.g. a national identifier) but often it is not. For this reason, none of the useful mechanisms described for working with references (e.g. chaining, includes) are possible, nor should servers be expected to be able resolve the reference. Servers may accept an identifier based reference untouched, resolve it, and/or reject it - see CapabilityStatement.rest.resource.referencePolicy. 

When both an identifier and a literal reference are provided, the literal reference is preferred. Applications processing the resource are allowed - but not required - to check that the identifier matches the literal reference

Applications converting a logical reference to a literal reference may choose to leave the logical reference present, or remove it.

Reference is intended to point to a structure that can potentially be expressed as a FHIR resource, though there is no need for it to exist as an actual FHIR resource instance - except in as much as an application wishes to actual find the target of the reference. The content referred to be the identifier must meet the logical constraints implied by any limitations on what resource types are permitted for the reference.  For example, it would not be legitimate to send the identifier for a drug prescription if the type were Reference(Observation|DiagnosticReport).  One of the use-cases for Reference.identifier is the situation where no FHIR representation exists (where the type is Reference (Any).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Literal reference, Relative, internal or absolute URL
definition.definition: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may be a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comment: Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries.   Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the URL conforms to the structure "/[type]/[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition:
The expected type of the target of the reference. If both Reference.type and Reference.reference are populated and Reference.reference is a FHIR URL, both SHALL be consistent.

The type is the Canonical URL of Resource Definition that is the type this reference refers to. References are URLs that are relative to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/ e.g. "Patient" is a reference to http://hl7.org/fhir/StructureDefinition/Patient. Absolute URLs are only allowed for logical models (and can only be used in references in logical models, not resources).
definition.comment: This element is used to indicate the type of  the target of the reference. This may be used which ever of the other elements are populated (or not). In some cases, the type of the target may be determined by inspection of the reference (e.g. a RESTful URL) or by resolving the target of the reference; if both the type and a reference is provided, the reference SHALL resolve to a resource of the same type as that specified.

definition.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

definition.definition: Indicates how quickly the Task should be addressed with respect to other requests.
definition.requirements: Used to identify the service level expected while performing a task.
definition.meaningWhenMissing: If missing, this task should be performed with normal priority

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The task's priority.

definition.definition: A description or code indicating why this task needs to be performed.
definition.comment: This should only be included if there is no focus or if it differs from the reason indicated on the focus.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Indicates why the task is needed.  E.g. Suspended because patient admitted to hospital.

reasonCode._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for CodeableConcept Type: A concept that may be defined by a formal reference to a terminology or ontology or may be provided by text.
reasonCode._root.name: CodeableConcept

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

definition.short: Code defined by a terminology system
definition.definition: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
definition.comment: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the HL7 v3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL NOT be used to infer meaning. Generally, at most only one of the coding values will be labeled as UserSelected = true.
definition.requirements: Allows for alternative encodings within a code system, and translations to other code systems.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

reasonCode.coding._root.description: Base StructureDefinition for Coding Type: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
reasonCode.coding._root.name: Coding

definition.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

definition.short: Symbol in syntax defined by the system
definition.definition: A symbol in syntax defined by the system. The symbol may be a predefined code or an expression in a syntax defined by the coding system (e.g. post-coordination).
definition.requirements: Need to refer to a particular code in the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.definition: A representation of the meaning of the code in the system, following the rules of the system.
definition.requirements: Need to be able to carry a human-readable meaning of the code for readers that do not know  the system.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: C*E.2 - but note this is not well followed

definition.definition: The identification of the code system that defines the meaning of the symbol in the code.
definition.comment: The URI may be an OID (urn:oid:...) or a UUID (urn:uuid:...).  OIDs and UUIDs SHALL be references to the HL7 OID registry. Otherwise, the URI should come from HL7's list of FHIR defined special URIs or it should reference to some definition that establishes the system clearly and unambiguously.
definition.requirements: Need to be unambiguous about the source of the definition of the symbol.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: If this coding was chosen directly by the user
definition.definition: Indicates that this coding was chosen by a user directly - e.g. off a pick list of available items (codes or displays).
definition.comment: Amongst a set of alternatives, a directly chosen code is the most appropriate starting point for new translations. There is some ambiguity about what exactly 'directly chosen' implies, and trading partner agreement may be needed to clarify the use of this element and its consequences more completely.
definition.requirements: This has been identified as a clinical safety criterium - that this exact system/code pair was chosen explicitly, rather than inferred by the system based on some rules or language processing.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:mapsTo dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected fhir:hasMap fhir:Coding.userSelected.map. fhir:Coding.userSelected.map a fhir:Map;   fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale. fhir:Coding.userSelected\#true a [     fhir:source "true";     fhir:target dt:CDCoding.codingRationale\#O   ]

definition.short: Version of the system - if relevant
definition.definition: The version of the code system which was used when choosing this code. Note that a well-maintained code system does not need the version reported, because the meaning of codes is consistent across versions. However this cannot consistently be assured, and when the meaning is not guaranteed to be consistent, the version SHOULD be exchanged.
definition.comment: Where the terminology does not clearly define what string should be used to identify code system versions, the recommendation is to use the date (expressed in FHIR date format) on which that version was officially published as the version date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

definition.short: Plain text representation of the concept
definition.definition: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.

definition.requirements: The codes from the terminologies do not always capture the correct meaning with all the nuances of the human using them, or sometimes there is no appropriate code at all. In these cases, the text is used to capture the full meaning of the source.
